document: Lecture 6 covers divide‑and‑conquer techniques such as merge sort, quicksort, binary search and the closest–pair problem.

questions.question: Merge sort divides the array into two halves recursively.
Quicksort's best‑case time complexity is O(n log n).
Binary search can be applied directly to a linked list.
The closest‑pair divide‑and‑conquer algorithm runs in Θ(n²) time without sorting.
In merge sort, the temporary array is allocated only once for all merges.
Quicksort can have a worst‑case O(n²) running time when the input is already sorted and the first element is chosen as pivot.
Binary search has a recurrence T(n)=1+T(n/2) for its worst case.
The closest‑pair problem can be solved in Θ(n log n) time using divide‑and‑conquer.
Merge sort's merge step takes linear time Θ(n).
Quicksort uses median‑of‑three pivot selection to improve performance.
Binary search requires the array to be sorted before searching.
Divide‑and‑conquer can also be applied for multiplication of large integers.
In the closest‑pair algorithm, points are sorted by y‑coordinate in the strip step.
Merge sort's time complexity is Θ(n²) if implemented poorly.
Quicksort eliminates recursion to improve performance.
Binary search stops when l > r condition fails.
The closest‑pair problem cannot be solved faster than O(n log n).
In merge sort, the array is split into halves of equal size.
Quicksort's partition step ensures all elements less than pivot are left of pivot in final position.
Binary search has optimal worst‑case time complexity for searching a sorted array.
